author: timbeiko
content:
Very speculative idea, but I wonder if there's not a way to get an MVP-1559 in Berlin almost, like: https://twitter.com/L_Nakaghini/status/1307075431447908353

TL;DR: burn X% of the transaction fee, period. I believe something like that had been discussed before. Main benefit is you split the upside of high fees between holders and miners. Obviously a lot of bike-shedding potential around the value of X, but it could be a sort of sliding scale where X is small at low gas prices, but high at high gas prices (and still a net benefit for miners).

author: nolan.ross
content: To expand my thoughts on this, my idea is that (using random dates I made up) say we are 6 months away from a successful 1559 implementation, but this idea would take 1 month to execute, it is probably worth it as 1559 is now 7 months away, but we get 6 months of some amount of fees being burnt and the pressure for 1559 to ship is lessened. If this idea takes 4 months to implement, it probably is not worth it.

author: nolan.ross
content: Of course we need to work around Berlin's schedule as well.

author: nolan.ross
content: I'm not qualified to evaluate the level of difficulty involved with implementing either idea.

author: .vbuterin
content: > TL;DR: burn X% of the transaction fee, period.

author: .vbuterin
content: So this doesn't work, because it's vulnerable to side channel payments

author: .vbuterin
content: Basically, miners have an incentive to make private agreements with tx senders where tx senders pay fees to miners through some other channel, and on-chain just put some nominal fee of eg. 1 gwei

author: .vbuterin
content: So the level of fee that gets burned has to be based on things that happen during historical blocks, it can't be a percentage of fee in the current block or anything like that

author: .vbuterin
content: So if you want a non-broken burn mechanic, then the simplest thing you can come up with basically is, EIP 1559 but without introducing the new transaction type

<@!552133098075193354> if you burn fees without the protocol enforced base-fee, on-chain fees will just drop to near-zero as the entire blockspace market moves off-chain. it would happen within weeks.

author: hasu0730
content:
in your proposal, you would say to miners and users "you guys figure it out among yourself how much you want to burn" - to which the answer is obviously zero. and hence zero is burned, as they collude against the protocol and ETH holders.

so the protocol has to say "to transact, you have to burn X". it's the only way

author: .funnyking
content:
> <@!552133098075193354> if you burn fees without the protocol enforced base-fee, on-chain fees will just drop to near-zero as the entire blockspace market moves off-chain. it would happen within weeks.
<@528251935829262351>  I did not understand. Could you please elaborate a bit?

author: .vbuterin
content: Suppose we have a "50% of fees get burned" rule

author: .vbuterin
content: Here is how we circumvent

author: .vbuterin
content: I make a private agreement with f2pool. I tell f2pool "I will send you txs privately through this channel, which will all have a tx fee of 1 wei, and I want you to include them. I will use this payment channel to pay you a fee for each transaction, equal to the gas consumed times 75% of the average gasprice of the block right before"

author: .vbuterin
content: F2pool's reasoning: ok, so now instead of getting 50% fees from the protocol, I get 75% fees from this channel

author: .vbuterin
content: My reasoning: so now instead of paying 100% fees to the protocol, I pay 75% fees to the channel

author: .vbuterin
content: (plus/minus a bit of variance because fees from adjacent blocks don't perfectly match, but over time that balances out and becomes not a very relevant factor)

author: .funnyking
content: Got it, thx
